Speaker: agafia
Dialogue: He needs to come in if he's to wash himself.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Good girl . . . good girl, Pava.

Speaker: kitchen maid
Dialogue: Agafia Mishaylovna says dinner's like to spoil.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: . . . her father's colour.

Speaker: vasili
Dialogue: Worth coming home for, Konstantin Dmitrich!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I stayed too long in Moscow.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: . . . She's a beauty. That's twelve cows sired by Berkut!

Speaker: agafia
Dialogue: So one of you is doing what the good Lord made you for.

Speaker: matvey
Dialogue: What should I do with this?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Where did you find it?

Speaker: matvey
Dialogue: In your hat. Your Excellency.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Yes . . . I picked it up somewhere for Daria Alexandrovna and the children.

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: Bonjour, Lili; bonjour, Masha; bonjour, Grisha; bonjour, Tanya.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Tsk, oh . . . Stiva!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: . . . and Dolly found a note from the governess.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Stiva wants me to come to Moscow . . . to persuade Dolly to forgive him.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I'm to be deprived of my wife so that adul- tery may be forgiven? I can't excuse him just because he's your brother.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: It's for Dolly's sake too.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I have four committees today . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Tsk-tsk, who put this shirt on you? Never mind. I'll come and hear you read.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Tomorrow, perhaps. Thank you, Lukich-- perhaps tomorrow.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Alexei, do you think nine years of mar- riage and children should count for nothing against a . . . an infatuation?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: No. Very well.  But sin has a price, you may be sure of that.

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: You think of the children! Their lives are ruined now!

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Oh, Dolly . . . I beg you . . .

Speaker: matvey
Dialogue: Telegram. Should I send up the barber?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: No, just the razor.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: My sister Anna's coming tomorrow. We're saved.

Speaker: doorkeeper
Dialogue: Some man came without an appointment, Your Excellency . . . waiting outside.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Levin! Where did you disappear?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I'm very anxious to see you. I need your advice.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: I've been hard at it. Sit down.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Hard at what exactly?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Why, we're overwhelmed with work!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Oh--paperwork.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Paperwork is the soul of Russia. Farming is only the stomach. When am I going to come and shoot some snipe?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Yes. I'm in love. I've come back to propose. Have you guessed who she is?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: I have a suspicion. Why didn't you propose when you were here?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I decided it was impossible. Kitty is of the heavens, an angel, and I am of the earth-- but then I thought and thought, and . . . there's no life for me without her! . . . Do I have a chance?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Of course you do. The Shcherbatskys are giving a soiree this evening. Get there early before the crowd. If I may suggest . . .

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Anything! What?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: New boots.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Right. Anything else?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: No--five-thirty at l'Angleterre--I owe them more than the Hermitage, so it wouldn't be fair to withdraw my custom.  Boots, and a coat. And a proper hat.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: It's so unfair. You marry for love, you're a good husband. Children arrive. Years depart. And all of a sudden your wife is tired, her hair is thin, her body . . . while you yourself still have your . . . vigour . . . and you find yourself distracted by a pretty woman . . .

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Forgive me, but I find that incomprehen- sible . . . As though I'd leave this restaurant and steal a roll from a baker's shop.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Well, you know, a freshly baked roll . . .

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: But I'm talking about love, and you're talk- ing about . . . your appetite.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Easily confused. Now look, do you know Count Vronsky?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Who? No. Why?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Who is he?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: You don't have to worry about him. He's one of those rich, good-looking cavalry offi- cers who've got nothing to do but make love to pretty women . . .

Speaker: elderly waiter
Dialogue: Potage aux choux a la Russe, as the gentle- man ordered.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: It's what I wanted.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Dolly said that? I've always thought your Dolly's a gem.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Oh, she is, she is . . .  I loved her to distraction.

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: But why?

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: But why?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I told you, Serozha. She's not well. I must go to see her.

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: But why?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Now, don't make Mama cry. I'll be back before you know, and bring you a present.

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: Don't want a present. I want you to stay.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Oh . . . my little Kutik . . .

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: What present?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: That's better.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: It's the first time I've left my little boy.

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: So you are leaving your son and I am return- ing to mine. I am Countess Vronsky.

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: But you know my name?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I've heard you mentioned . . .

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: Talked about, you mean. Ah, love!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Was it love?

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: Always. My sons are ashamed of me. But I'd rather end up wishing I hadn't than end up wishing I had--wouldn't you?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I . . . I don't know . . .

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I'll come back.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Konstantin!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I'm too early.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: No! Come up!

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Look at me! I'm receiving for Papa and Maman who are late to dress. It's my first reception.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Princess Ekaterina! Delighted, delighted!

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: I'm so pleased you were able to be with us, Konstantin Dmitrich!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Kitty . . . you look . . . you look--

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Stiva told us you were back. How long are you staying?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I don't know. It depends on you.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: On me?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: What I mean to say--I came with only one purpose--I want to--will you be my wife?

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: I can't. I'm sorry.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Yes. It was impossible.

Speaker: burisov
Dialogue: Burisov. Are you the brother of Nikolai Levin?

Speaker: burisov
Dialogue: He's in Moscow, he's staying at the Unicorn in Khitrovka.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: How do you know?

Speaker: burisov
Dialogue: It's the sort of thing I know.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Count Vronsky?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: It's Kostya.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Nothing. I came to see you.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Good evening, miss . . . madame . . .

Speaker: nikolai
Dialogue: Don't talk to her like that. It frightens her. You sound like a magistrate.  More vodka for my brother, quick about it.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I don't want anything.

Speaker: nikolai
Dialogue: I'm all right.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: A colonel in the Third Department. They're watching you.

Speaker: nikolai
Dialogue: Good. They must think I'm dangerous.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: nikolai
Dialogue: That's right. The day is coming. I gave up my birthright for it. You're on the wrong side of history. Not because privilege is immoral but because it's irrational.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: He is sick.

Speaker: nikolai
Dialogue: Let go or I'll beat your lights out.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: nikolai
Dialogue: Why not? Are you waiting to fall in love?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: nikolai
Dialogue: Good. Romantic love will be the last illu- sion of the old order. You should marry one of your peasants.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Yes. I damn well should!

Speaker: nikolai
Dialogue: The brotherhood of man.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Nikolai, you have to see a doctor. Then come and stay with me at Pokrovskoe till you get your health back.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: If you . . . or go abroad to a spa. I'll send you more if that's what you . . .

Speaker: stationmaster
Dialogue: The private coach will stop opposite the carpet.

Speaker: guards officer
Dialogue: Austrian royalty on their honeymoon. I've got them for four days.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Bad luck. What do they like? Art?

Speaker: guards officer
Dialogue: Food.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Here's the train.

Speaker: stationmaster
Dialogue: I'll see to it.

Speaker: major domo
Dialogue: Second carriage, Your Excellency. I'll see to the Countess's luggage and bring it on to the house.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You don't look ashamed.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: I am, I really am.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Charmante, don't you think?  Wait for me in the carriage. I'll take Tosca.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: . . . You stayed longer in St. Petersburg.

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: Long enough for you to start a little love affair, I hear.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I can't think what you're referring to, Maman.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: There, Countess, you have found your son and I have found my brother.

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: Madame Karenin has a son, too. It's the first time they have been apart, so she frets about him.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Excuse me for not recognizing you before.

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: We passed the time telling each other about our sons.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes, I've been hearing all about you.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: That must have been very boring for you.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Au revoir, Countess.

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: Au revoir, my dear. Let me kiss your pretty face.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Keep your people inside until this has been cleared up.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: . . . the sole support of a large family, they say.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Wait for me, Maman.

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: I've you to thank for that.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: What a good fellow . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Have you known Count Vronsky long?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Did you like him? He's in love with Kitty.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Oh . . .  But we should be discussing you and Dolly.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: I've said it all--on my knees--in tears . . . Now I need you to say it. I'm going to the office, so you'll have Dolly to yourself.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Don't be home late.

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: Kitty's coming by to see you. She's all grown-up, and a bit frightened of you--the belle of St. Petersburg society!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Is that who I am?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I know, I know.

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: I can't bear to be with him. And he doesn't care, he's got what he wants.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What he wants is you. He loves you, Dolly. You and the children are everything to him.

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: Are we? And there is room for a governess?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: That was shameful, disgraceful. But it was not love. It was the animal in man, not the soul. Stiva's remorse is from the soul.

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: What about me? Does his remorse make it easier for me?--

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I know you are suffering. But, Dolly, you must tell me . . . is there enough love left in your heart . . . enough to forgive him?

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: When I think of them together, I can't for- give him, no!

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: My fate?  But I haven't done anything! It's him WHO'S--

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Do you love him, Dolly?

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Will you stay for the Bobrishchev's ball, Anna?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Oh . . . I always feel dull at a ball.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: How can you ever be dull?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Of course she must.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: . . . and God go with you.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: You can introduce me to your new governess.

Speaker: tanya
Dialogue: She's old! She's a hundred!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I know why you want me to come. You want everyone to be there because you're sure it's going to be your night.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: How did you know?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I know everything.

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: . . . no, Your Excellency . . . He's just gone up. . . . The Princess retired early . . . Is there a message?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Will you go to confession?

Speaker: serafina
Dialogue: And you also, master. He is watching.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: God forgive us then, for committing the act of love.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: "Not according to my deserts, O Lord, but according to thy mercy"--that's a fine prayer. But I'm full of doubt. Sometimes I even doubt that God exists.

Speaker: serafina
Dialogue: How can there be anything if God didn't make it?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I don't know. One day science will tell us.

Speaker: serafina
Dialogue: That's sinful talk if the priest heard you.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Well, I won't go to confession.

Speaker: serafina
Dialogue: Your father built the church. You're con- fessed a while yet.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: What would you like?

Speaker: youth
Dialogue: Kitty! May I have a waltz?

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: You may, Boris. I'll save you the third just because it's your first ball.

Speaker: youth
Dialogue: You're my first conquest.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: There.

Speaker: korsunsky
Dialogue: So that your ankles may be seen.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: How are you, Stiva?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Thanks to Anna, I am a happy man. Would you like to dance?

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: No, ask Anna.

Speaker: prince shcherbatsky
Dialogue: . . . this vile, idiotic matchmaking of yours . . .

Speaker: princess shcherbatsky
Dialogue: For goodness' sake, what have I done?

Speaker: prince shcherbatsky
Dialogue: Levin is a thousand times better than this Petersburg fop. If he had royal blood my daughter wouldn't need him!

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Is anything the matter?

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Don't ask me, Maman!

Speaker: countess nordston
Dialogue: He'll dance the mazurka with Kitty, you'll see. I call the mazurka the now-or-never.

Speaker: austrian princess
Dialogue: . . . we were shut up in the train for an hour!

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Dance with me.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I am not used to being spoken to like that by a man I met once at a railway station.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I dare say, but if I'm not to dance with you, I'm getting out of this operetta and going home.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Then, for Kitty's sake.

Speaker: countess nordston
Dialogue: You're not dancing the mazurka? I won't have it.

Speaker: korsunsky
Dialogue: . . . the lady chooses a lady and a gentleman . . . !

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Bologoye! Fifteen minutes.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Can I be of service to you?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I didn't know you were . . . Why are you leaving?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: This is wrong. If you're a good man, forget everything that happened, as I will.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I'll never forget a single thing about you, not a word, not a gesture--

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: That's enough!

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Take the luggage home.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Is Serozha all right?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Did you have a good night?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes, quite comfortable. Count Vronsky.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I have to get back to the Committee . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I? Oh--Dolly and Stiva . . . yes, I think so . . .

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I'll announce myself.

Speaker: petritsky
Dialogue: Vronsky! The master himself. Baroness, coffee from the new coffeepot for Count Vronsky.

Speaker: baroness
Dialogue: I'll be off home if I'm in the way.

Speaker: baroness
Dialogue: Ah!--Pierre, you never say such pretty things to me. We were just discussing my husband. He won't divorce me, you see. And do you know why?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: baroness
Dialogue: Because he likes eating off my family silver.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Ah.

Speaker: baroness
Dialogue: I want to bring an action. Just because I'm supposed to be unfaithful, I don't see why I have to eat off Pierre's crockery. Look at it.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: It's my crockery.

Speaker: petritsky
Dialogue: How was Moscow?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Provincial.

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: You've stopped.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Sssh . . .

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Time for bed!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I'm writing to Dolly . . . and to Kitty.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: You are . . . good.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: What are they saying in Moscow about the new Statute?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What new Statute?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: The new Statute I carried in Council.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: No one mentioned it.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Ah. Really?

Speaker: family doctor
Dialogue: Forgive me, Princess, but I must . . .

Speaker: prince shcherbatsky
Dialogue: Am I the only one who knows what's wrong with her?

Speaker: princess shcherbatsky
Dialogue: Oh, thank God, doctor--my friends say you're the only one who can save her!

Speaker: celebrity doctor
Dialogue: Possibly, Princess, possibly! At your service, Your Excellencies. Where is the patient?

Speaker: celebrity doctor
Dialogue: Come, come, Princess, we are not backward people--I handle naked bodies every day. Deep breath now . . .

Speaker: prince shcherbatsky
Dialogue: By God. I'll challenge the scoundrel!

Speaker: family doctor
Dialogue: It's the modern way . . .

Speaker: princess shcherbatsky
Dialogue: You're not a doctor!

Speaker: family doctor
Dialogue: Her symptoms . . . loss of appetite, fast PULSE--

Speaker: prince shcherbatsky
Dialogue: Well, whose pulse wouldn't be fast if some brute of a--

Speaker: prince shcherbatsky
Dialogue: Don't you fret, my little Kate! You'll wake up one fine morning and say to yourself--"I feel well and happy and I'll go out for a walk with Papa!"

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: I want to give a small dinner before the opera. Is there anyone you would like me to ask?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes . . . Yes, the Metropolitan Bishop of St. Petersburg.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: The last one was to meet a missionary, the one before was for a lecture on the union of the Greek and Roman churches.  I'm sorry--I know you're fond of her. Come on, or we'll be late.

Speaker: demin
Dialogue: Here's the thing, Vronsky. A posting has come up and there's a promotion in it for you.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: demin
Dialogue: The garrison in Tashkent.

Speaker: demin
Dialogue: I don't mind. But your mother . . .

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: You didn't come to my dinner.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I had to see my Commanding Officer.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: . . . work never ceases for great men.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I'm expected at the Tverskoys.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: No doubt, but I'm sure Princess Betsy can wait for you, my dear.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes. In fact, I think I won't go to Betsy's.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: You're caught.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I'm afraid I am becoming ridiculous.

Speaker: lisa merkalova
Dialogue: Now, there's a phenomenon, look-- Anna's shadow has arrived before Anna!

Speaker: anna's friend
Dialogue: I'm Anna's friend . . . but this making-up- one's-mind-to-it in public is not polite to a distinguished man like Karenin.

Speaker: princess myagkaya
Dialogue: In my opinion Karenin is a fool, and Anna is the best of us.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Alexei . . . You look desperate. That's not attractive.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I'm losing hope.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Hope of what? Persuading a virtuous woman to break her marriage vows?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: And how is Tuskevich?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: That's not attractive either. Besides, I was never virtuous.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: No--you're right. She won't come. I'm going home.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Turn round!

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: Wasn't Nilsson glorious? One sees that she has studied Kaulbach, of course . . .

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: He's gone. But you're just in time for the surprise.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I would prefer to try a cigarette.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Just as I was thinking your manners have improved since Moscow. You behaved badly, very badly.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: And who was responsible for that?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Give me a cup of tea.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: How nice--Alexei Aleksandrevich has arrived.

Speaker: lisa merkalova
Dialogue: I'm not sure my nerves can stand another Alexei at this moment.

Speaker: princess myagkaya
Dialogue: So the Schuzburgs asked us to dinner. The sauce was said to have cost a thousand rou- bles, and it was ghastly. We had to ask them back. I gave them a sauce that cost eighty- five kopeks and it was a triumph.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Were you glad to see me or not?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: What do you want me to do?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I want you to go to Moscow and beg Kitty to forgive you.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: No, that's not what you want. Moscow? I can do better than that. Tonight I refused a posting to Tashkent. I can change my mind, and you'll never see me again.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: If you have any thought for me, you will give me back my peace.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I have no peace to give. There can be no peace for us--only misery or the greatest happiness. You are my whole life now.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Your husband is impossible!-- his opinions are all wrong but he talks so brilliantly he wins every argument.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I called to take you home.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: No, I'm staying. Send the carriage back for me.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Do you want me to go to Tashkent?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: So I'll go to Tashkent.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: No. I don't want you to go.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Waiting up? How unlike you!

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Yes, I stayed up to talk to you.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What about? It's late. Where's Annushka?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I sent her off.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Well, if you want to talk, but we should go to bed.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Warn me? It's really rather late . . .

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I wish to warn you that you may inadver- tently, by indiscretion and carelessness, give the world occasion to talk about you.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I am not a committee. Please say what you want to tell me.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: You and Count Vronsky attracted attention tonight.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You don't like it when I don't talk to people, and you don't like it when I do.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I didn't notice anything, myself. But I saw that everyone else noticed. I consider jeal- ousy to be insulting to you and degrading to me. I have no right to inquire into your feelings. They concern only your conscience. But I'm your husband and I love you. It's my duty to remind you that we are bound together by God, and this bond can only be broken by a crime against God.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: And you have a son.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Forgive me.  If I am wrong, I ask your pardon.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I don't know what you're talking about, and it's really too late for this. Excuse me, please.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Too late.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Oh God forgive me. It's the end of everything--I've got nothing left now, only you. Remember that.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Anna . . . Anna . . . how can I not remem- ber? You're my happiness.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I thought that had been done.

Speaker: vasili
Dialogue: I gave the order. What can you do with these people?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Ah--potage aux choux a la Russe!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Of Babylon? No.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: You're right, what do you care? You love the country--you've got it. You love agricultur- ing, and, Lord knows, you've got it. You love shooting--you've got it. You've got every- thing you want!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: All right, go on, then. Have you stopped stealing bread rolls?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: So, nothing new to tell me. How is--how are the Shcherbatskys?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: You mean Kitty.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I . . . Is she engaged now?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: No. Vronsky went back to St. Petersburg.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Oh yes, as if I had time in the summer! And I've got extra land this year at Kashin for the haymaking.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Kashin? That's on the Ergoshovo road, isn't it? Won't you call when Kitty is there?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Especially not then. I humiliated myself once.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Her heart told her no. Did you come to shoot snipe or criticize me?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: For you, getting married is . . . a social engage- ment. Not for me. For me, it's the condition of personal happiness and living the right way. I'll never again be carried away by passion. I renounce it. I'll have to find another way . . .

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Look out--here they come!

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: There. Oh, I'm sore with his feeding! Would you like to hold him?

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: I have no troubles.

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: That man wasn't worth the tears, believe me.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: I don't care about him. I don't even think about him. Or her. Except to hate her.

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: Then we'll never speak of it again.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: What has Levin got to do with it? Anyway, I'll never get married. The whole business of . . . it's become disgusting to me . . . and look what it's done for you! Why do they call it love?

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: Because it's love.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I want you to. I don't care about it.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: You should care. You're not supposed to.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Everybody. Doctors.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You're squeamish. You a soldier! Would you faint?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Anyway, someone might be watching.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: But I'm damned anyway.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I'm not. I'm blessed.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You love me.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Only me.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Apart from Frou-Frou.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: But me more than your horse?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Are you happy?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: And you love me?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: This much.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: This much?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: This much?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: This much? And this much? And this much?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: And . . . this . . . much . . . ?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Countess . . . I thought you would be at Peterhof now.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: I've come from there. I'm distressed that you haven't taken your usual house this year.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Anna wanted a change. She is spending the summer at Tsarskoe.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Near Princess Betsy. And . . .

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Oh, is this about my wife?

Speaker: alexander
Dialogue: Alyosha . . . a message from Maman. Her friend Princess Sorokina has a house here, and a virgin daughter, that's not part of the

Speaker: demin
Dialogue: Gentlemen--I give you--the regiment!

Speaker: alexander
Dialogue: I heard you turned down a promotion.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: That was Maman interfering.

Speaker: alexander
Dialogue: Yes. And now she's come up with a princess for you.  Alexei--we're brothers, so don't take offence. Getting married puts the pack on your back--it leaves your hands free for climbing the ladder. Getting serious about a married woman is like carrying your pack in your arms.

Speaker: alexander
Dialogue: An assignation?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Come on, I'll introduce you.

Speaker: alexander
Dialogue: Beautiful. A man would come to no harm. Do you think you'll win tomorrow?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Makhotin's Gladiator is favourite, sixteen hands--Frou-Frou looks dainty beside him, but she's got heart. Haven't you, my darling?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Alexei, what is it?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I couldn't bear not to see you before the race.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I'm pregnant.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Ah . . . My love.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: How can we, Alexei?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Tell Karenin everything.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Do you think my husband will make you a present of me?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Leave him.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Leave him and be your mistress?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Yes. Run away.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I would never see my son again. The laws are made by husbands and fathers.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: What, then? I'll never forgive myself for your unhappiness.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: How are you, young man? Your tutor doesn't seem to be in evidence. We'll have a look at your lesson books.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Alexei!--you got away at last. Can you stay?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Why . . . ?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Races, surely. No, I'll come on later, and then I must get back to town.

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: Exquisite creature . . . you really ought to be the spoil of victory today . . .

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Princess! A bet! What do you fancy in the next?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Kusolev.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: I'm on Vronsky. A pair of gloves?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Alexei . . . !

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I'm here.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Stiva! What are they saying?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Vronsky's unhurt--but the horse . . .

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Her back's broken!

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I'm asking you . . . if you wish to go . . .

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: I'll bring her home, Alexei.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Excuse me, Princess, but Anna is not well and I want her to come with me.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: You know . . . they say the Emperor dis- approves of the races . . . the danger of injury . . . but I . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I'm saying there is a value in manly sport, for the military--

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: In my opinion, it's not the sport itself that's wrong, it's the spectacle, it's making a cruel spectacle out of--

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I have to tell you--

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I have to tell you, you behaved improperly today.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: And how was that?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: By making plain your feelings when one of the riders fell. Your conduct was improper. It must not occur again. I have said it before.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: No, you were not mistaken. I love him. I am his mistress. I can't bear you, I'm afraid of you, I hate you. Do what you like to me.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Wait, please. Move away.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Are you hurt?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: What's happened?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I told him I'm your mistress.

Speaker: major domo
Dialogue: Their Excellencies Minister Karenin and Madame Karenin!

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Alexei Aleksandrevich . . . congratulations. You're the only man my husband would do this for.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Tell me your latest find for your library.

Speaker: prince tverskoy
Dialogue: Not in front of the Princess.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: I can tell you're happy. You've put on a little weight.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Both true.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Time for bed!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Alexei . . . I can't . . . I'm sorry . . . But I'm his wife now.  I am having his child.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Tell me what I did to deserve this.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: How many mowers is it, Theodore?

Speaker: theodore
Dialogue: Forty-two, master. In your father's time it was work for two days for thirty men . . .  . . . though he never picked up a scythe himself.

Speaker: theodore
Dialogue: They like what they're used to.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: It settles me.

Speaker: theodore
Dialogue: How is that, master?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: When I'm mowing, I don't ask myself why I'm here.

Speaker: theodore
Dialogue: You're here to be master, Konstantin Dmi- trich, to be your father's son, and father to a son who will be master after you, as it has always been by the grace of God.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: My father owned you, Theodore. My grand- father owned your father. Owned you like chattels, to be bought and sold. Was that by the grace of God?

Speaker: theodore
Dialogue: It was. Those were good times when your father had the keeping of us. That's my youngest you were looking at there. His young life is perilous now since the Free- dom came and work must be found.

Speaker: theodore
Dialogue: At his wife too, I dare say.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: They look happier than I've ever been. Is it living simply that I'm looking for?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: He's some kind of prince at home. Exhaust- ing. Where is Tuskevitch this evening?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Why ask me?

Speaker: makhotin
Dialogue: Lucky woman. Give her my respects, and to Karenin if you see him.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Don't. Would you compromise me? And Lisa?

Speaker: stremov
Dialogue: I only say that a man who can't govern his wife has perhaps gone as far as he can go in government.

Speaker: kapitonich
Dialogue: Good evening, Your Excellency.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I am expected.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: It's punishment enough that I'm on escort duty, without . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes--I'm sorry--it's my demon, I can't help it.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: You wrote that you were ill.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Did I? Well, I am!  But don't worry! It won't be for long, I'll soon be out of your way--soon!

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Stop.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: No, it's true. I was told it in a dream.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes, and I'm only going to die having your baby.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: That's all nonsense!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Tell me it is, tell me it is. You love me. Only me.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Your note said your husband would be out.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: He was late. Serves him right. And you. Why do you call him my husband? He isn't my husband--he's a clock, a wooden doll--

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: But it was awkward . . . a matter of your honour. You made an agreement.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Do you think of my honour when you're sharing whores with your Hindoo!

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Your demon again!

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Anna . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Put your hand there. There! Did you feel him move!

Speaker: stremov
Dialogue: I must respectfully ask Minister Karenin whether his proposals for the regulation of these colourful Gypsy tribes, of these schol- arly God-fearing Jews, and of--but I'm afraid I have lost the Minister's attention . . .

Speaker: kapitonich
Dialogue: Only Madame, Your Excellency.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I wanted to see him because . . .

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I do not wish to be told why a woman wants to see her lover.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What are you . . . ?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I want his letters.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Alexei . . . please . . . leave me Serozha . . . !

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Do you think I would let you have my son? You are depraved, a woman without honour. I thank God the curse of love is lifted from me.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Levin! What . . . ?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I need your advice . . .

Speaker: countess nordston
Dialogue: Well, is he coming?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Am I late? Who is here?

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Of course you're late! Come and meet . . . Countess Nordston.

Speaker: prince shcherbatsky
Dialogue: Come into the fold . . .

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: Kitty is here.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Konsantin . . . what a long time since we saw each other.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Since you saw me, but I saw you not so long ago.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: You were driving to Ergoshovo . . . I was at Kashin for the haymaking.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Oh, but why didn't you . . . ?

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: I hope not--I was young and silly in those days.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Months and months ago!

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: And you haven't changed.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: No. I haven't.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Permit me to announce--soup Marie Lou- ise, carp with asparagus, and roast beef! I went to the market in person!

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I've been on tour in the regions, a govern- ment commission . . . I'm sorry--I have come to tell you our connection must be severed. I'm going to divorce your sister.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Divorce? Dear me, what are you talking about? Don't be in a hurry. Stay to dinner and later talk it over with Dolly--

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Prince Oblonsky, everything is over between our families.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Alexei . . . divorce is one thing but dinner is quite another.

Speaker: princess shcherbatsky
Dialogue: You Petersburgers think yourselves so de bon ton compared with dull, old-fashioned

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: Well, what's this government commission, Karenin . . . ?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: What was the challenge about?

Speaker: princess shcherbatsky
Dialogue: Pryachnikov's wife, naturally.

Speaker: prince shcherbatsky
Dialogue: It was a matter of honour, defending a woman's honour . . .

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: It sounds like barbarism to me . . . And what if the lover had killed the husband?-- would that have preserved the wife's honour too?

Speaker: countess nordston
Dialogue: Still, not many of us can say that our lover died for love!

Speaker: countess nordston
Dialogue: Would you die for love, Konstantin Dmitrich?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I would. But not for my neighbour's wife.

Speaker: countess nordston
Dialogue: Ah, an idealist!

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I tried to save her. She chose ruin.

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: Alexei Aleksandrevich--look at me. You will have no peace of mind until you forgive her. It was Anna who taught me that.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I do not wish to forgive. I am not a cruel man. I have never hated anyone. But I hate her with all my soul for all the wrong she has done me.

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: It's your turn to play us something, Countess.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Since we last met, there is something I have often wanted to ask you.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Do Not . . .

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I know what it says.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Die, then.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: How is your mistress?

Speaker: kapitonich
Dialogue: Safely delivered of a daughter, Your Excellency.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: So . . . she is well?

Speaker: kapitonich
Dialogue: The mistress is very poorly. The doctor . . .

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: She's dying. Please let me stay.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Thank God! She talks only of you.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Why doesn't he come? He is kind. He will forgive me.

Speaker: midwife
Dialogue: He's here--look--look--can't you see him?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I want Alexei! Why doesn't he come? Give me some water. No, I mustn't, it's not good for my little girl. Or let her have a nurse. Yes--don't bring her here, because Alexei is coming and it will hurt him to see her.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: More ice.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Oh, what nonsense. I must be asleep, that's what it is. You think he won't forgive me but you don't know him. No one knows him except me. I'm not afraid of him now.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Take your hands away from your face. Look at my husband. He's a saint! Take his hand. Alexei--take his hands away.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Whatever you think of me, please believe me, I love her--I could not have done other- wise than what I . . . what I did.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: But you must leave now. I promise to send for you if she asks for you. I don't know what happened. I forgive you. I forgive Anna. My soul is filled with joy. I will remain with her and look after her for ever.

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: Look at you. You look like what you are. A laughingstock. I fancy you are to be asked to leave the regiment.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I would like you to go, Maman.

Speaker: countess vronsky
Dialogue: I will go when I'm ready to go. A little affair with a married woman puts a finish- ing touch to a young man's education--but this morbid, selfish obsession . . . ! You have publicly humiliated a man who has devoted his life to Russia, and it will not be forgot- ten. You'd better come back to Moscow with me. You're finished here.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: In Petersburg?  I'm finished here.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: . . . no, I'll go to her and tell her it's not too late to stop this business! Better now than when we're married and she realises she doesn't love me!

Speaker: oblonsky
Dialogue: But she does love you!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: How can she? I mean, look at me! Suppose she's only marrying me to get married? Suppose she's still in love with Vronsky?

Speaker: matvey
Dialogue: Your coat, sir.

Speaker: princess shcherbatsky
Dialogue: Konstantin!--what-- ?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I have to talk to Kitty.

Speaker: princess shcherbatsky
Dialogue: You're not allowed to see her!

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: No. I don't understand at all! What's the matter with you?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: You can't love me. Think it over! Let people say what they like!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Yes. If you don't love me.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: But I do love you!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Do you? Well, I love you!

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Oh, Konstantin!

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: . . . and there was her husband wearing her best ballgown, rouge all over his face . . . ma chere, le scandale! . . . But I'd better tell you some regimental news . . .

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Who is here?

Speaker: footman
Dialogue: Princess Elisabeth Federovna Tverskaya, Your Excellency.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Please excuse me.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: No--stay.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: You look feverish.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: We have been talking too much--so I'm going.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Princess Betsy came to tell me . . .

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Goodbye, my treasure.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I agree with you. As he is going away, there is no need for Count Vronsky to come here.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: But it is for you to decide.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes, and I decided.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Then I am very glad that--

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: That we agree, so perhaps we can stop talk- ing about it.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Of course. Is there anything I can do for you?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes, can you please please please stop crack- ing your knuckles.  I'm a bad woman. But I can't breathe. Your kindness which I can't repay, and your FORGIVENESS--

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: You begged me for my forgiveness.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: But I didn't die and now I have to live with it! If only you would have gone on hating me.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Not to say goodbye.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I can't hear.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Not to say goodbye.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: You would be lost. Irretrievably lost. You would have no position. And worse if we divorce. You would be the guilty party. That means you cannot legally remarry. Your union with Count Vronsky would be illegitimate, and so would your daughter who now has the protection of my name. And that is what you want! It would be a sin to help you destroy yourself.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You forget something. Count Vronsky and I love each other.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: And this love sanctifies a criminal folly?

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: I see. And Serozha . . . ?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I would die for him, but I won't live like this for him. When he knows about love, he'll forgive me.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Then I must choose the smaller sin. Vronsky robbed me of my cloak and I will give him my coat. I will give you grounds to divorce me, and I'll accept the scandal, the humilia- tion and the consequences to my career.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: No . . . I can't . . .

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: You may write to him but I would prefer you not to see him until you have left this house.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: You look like a boy. But so pale. We'll go south . . . to the sea air and sunshine . . .

Speaker: slyudin
Dialogue: . . . and Madame Odette in person, so to speak, Your Excellency, with your permission . . .

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Madame Odette . . . ?

Speaker: shopkeeper
Dialogue: Excuse the liberty, Your Excellency . . . it's for a bonnet and some ribbons Her Excel- lency has overlooked. If you wish us to address ourselves to Her Excellency, please be so good as to tell us where we might . . .

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: I have forced my way in! I have heard!

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: Countess, every shopkeeper has heard.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: My dear friend! Don't give way to sorrow. Our Lord Jesus Christ has you in his care.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: No, I'm done for. I don't understand any- thing. All day long I'm being asked to make decisions about bills and servants, the kitchen, Serozha's clothes . . .

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: I understand. I understand everything. I am going to act. The household arrangements you can leave to me. I will come every day. I will be a second mother to Serozha.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: This is Agafia, and Vasili, the steward . . . My wife, Ekaterina Alexandrovna Levin.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: I am very pleased to meet you both.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: And that was Kuzma. Come inside!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Is it all right?

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: No--I want to see everything.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: A moment.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: It's me, Konstantin.

Speaker: nikolai
Dialogue: Yes, good. The doctor here is useless--get me a doctor from Moscow.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Where did you go? I asked for you every- where, when I was getting married.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: I'm sorry . . . I couldn't leave him. I know I've done wrong.

Speaker: agafia
Dialogue: I couldn't go against Nikolai Dmitrich's orders . . .

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Yes--yes . . . She's going.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I will nurse him with Agafia . . . The woman will find somewhere in the village. You won't see her. She knows it's impossible for you to meet her. It is a torment to me that I have brought you under the same roof

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Good. A clean nightshirt and sheets. A towel and a clean pail of warm water. Ask Agafia for vinegar, and to prepare a bed somewhere for Masha. Wait.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: I'm not looking.

Speaker: nikolai
Dialogue: I'm going . . .

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Thank you, Father . . . and how much . . . ?

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: You're such an expert on love, Kostya . . . why didn't you know it when you saw it?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Alexei, they're back! Here in St. Petersburg! She has written to me.

Speaker: karenin
Dialogue: To you? . . . I think I don't have the right to refuse . . . It's the boy's birthday . . .

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: My friend . . . you would be blowing on the embers of a fire which must be allowed to die . . . Let me write to her.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I'm here to see Sergei Alexeyich.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I have brought something for Sergei Alexeyich.

Speaker: kapitonich
Dialogue: He is not up yet. Would you wish to wait? Who shall I say . . . ?

Speaker: kapitonich
Dialogue: Please allow me!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I've come to see Sergei Alexeyich.

Speaker: kapitonich
Dialogue: He's been moved to the small sitting room.

Speaker: kapitonich
Dialogue: I'll just look in.

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: Mama.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Oh, my dear little boy.

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: I knew you would come. Today is my birthday.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I won't cry. It's time for you to get dressed. And I almost forgot your present, look . . . open it . . .

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: You don't want that . . . Let me see.

Speaker: korney
Dialogue: It's your fault for letting her in!--you should be sacked.

Speaker: kapitonich
Dialogue: Oh yes, you would have sent her packing! Ten years I've been keeping the door and the mistress was always kind to me. You should stick to stealing the master's clothes.

Speaker: lukich
Dialogue: I've had enough of this--it's my job to get the boy out of bed before His Excellency comes . . .

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: Don't go!--he's not coming yet.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes, I must, and you must love Papa-- he's better than I am. When you're grown-up . . .

Speaker: serozha
Dialogue: No one in the whole world is better than you.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Where's Anya?

Speaker: annushka
Dialogue: She's still asleep. Should I take your coat?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I'm not sleeping.

Speaker: annushka
Dialogue: I can send out for something.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Why are you in the dark?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: To where? To whom?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I didn't know what happened to you.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: But I told you yesterday . . . My brother . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Does it take all day for you to meet your brother? Does he need you more than I do?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: What's happened?

Speaker: yashvin
Dialogue: It's wonderful to have you both returned.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: How good you are to come. You're the very first person to call on me since our return.

Speaker: yashvin
Dialogue: But perhaps you'll meet at the opera tonight?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I would love to be there if I could get a box.

Speaker: yashvin
Dialogue: Madame, your box is number four! You'll find me there with Princess Myagkaya. Will you come, Vronsky?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I see why . . . Alexei is so fond of you.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: You know you can't go to the theatre?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Annushka!

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: For heaven's sake--

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: A bath. I'll come in and choose a dress.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Anna--I implore you--don't you know . . . ?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I'm not ashamed of who I am or what I've done: are you ashamed for me? Why do you keep a room at the hotel? Aren't we together? Have you changed towards me?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: It's because I love you and care about you.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: That would make it worse.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You're afraid. Well, I'm not.

Speaker: princess myagkaya
Dialogue: Anna . . . !

Speaker: princess myagkaya
Dialogue: Should we visit or stay put?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Stay put.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: You'll come up to see us afterwards . . . ?

Speaker: alexander
Dialogue: Talk to Varya.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Will you call on Anna?

Speaker: varya
Dialogue: Oh, Alexei . . . I'm fond of you . . . but . . .

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: For God's sake, Anna isn't a criminal!

Speaker: varya
Dialogue: I'd call on her if she'd only broken the law. But she broke the rules.

Speaker: princess myagkaya
Dialogue: Who has made the decor? Haven't we got a programme? Colonel, would you be so kind . . . ?

Speaker: yashvin
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Thank you, how very . . .

Speaker: prince tverskoy
Dialogue: Catullus, printed in Venice, 1501 . . . remarkable.

Speaker: house manager
Dialogue: A thousand apologies, Princess, but . . .

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Captain Makhotin . . .

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Fetch my cloak!

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: What are we coming to?

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: Yes, why don't you? Rescue her and put your seal on the fiasco.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: As far as I'm concerned, she's my wife.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: But, as you saw, she isn't.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: We're going to Moscow, and then to my place in the country.

Speaker: betsy
Dialogue: That sounds like a good idea.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: But for a day or two, Anna will be at home, at my flat.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: . . . you had an excellent night! Does your mother want you to marry the widow or the child?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Either one.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Don't make a joke of it. If you loved me, you would have locked me in to stop me going.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Go to bed.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I won't sleep.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I know how to make you sleep.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: No, no--you don't. Kitty and her husband are with us. She's in Moscow to have the baby.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Kitty . . . ? Oh, tell her how pleased I am . . . !

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: Perhaps I'll wait a year or two.  Oh . . . love!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes . . . love! Don't you disapprove of me for what I've done?

Speaker: dolly
Dialogue: No. I wish I'd done the same. But no one asked me! Well . . . I wouldn't have been brave enough.  Stiva, you know . . . he doesn't change . . . like all men, I suppose.

Speaker: annushka
Dialogue: Madame . . . Madame . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What time is it? Is Anya up?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I'm all right. It's all right.  Get them to bring up all our trunks and travel cases. We've been here long enough.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I had an inspiration. Why do we have to wait here? Why can't we wait in the coun- try? I don't want to hear any more about a divorce, or think about it.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Good! I'm bored here. When should we go?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: If I bore you here, I'll bore you in the country.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I didn't say you bore me. Moscow bores me. When should we go? . . . Tomorrow?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: The day after, then.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: If you like.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: No, wait. That's Sunday. I have to see Maman.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: That's twenty minutes away in the train-- you could go to see her tomorrow--or was it that you wanted to spend Sunday with Princess Sorokina?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Please don't spoil everything. I can't see Maman tomorrow because she won't have read the papers she has to sign. Oh, and then there's the bank . . . But we can leave on Tuesday.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: In that case, let's not bother. I'll leave on Sunday or not at all.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: That's absurd!

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Anna . . . Anna . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You've stopped loving me. You've given up everything for me, and it's turned you against me. Why lie about it?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Stop. I put off our departure for a day or two, and you tell me I don't love you.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Because I've been living off your love and there's none left, so this is over! Finished.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I don't mind when we go.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I'll telegraph Maman. We'll go on Sunday. I'll do anything you want.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I don't want to. I love you.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: You can't ask why about love.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: So--will you be all packed? I'll be out today making the arrangements.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Is that your way of telling me you'll be at your mother's with that simpering little princess?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Well, I know what that means.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: My God, this is unendurable.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Thank you, but if I'm not fit to dine in soci- ety, I won't eat with the band. Who was the telegram from?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: I didn't show it to you, because Stiva keeps telegraphing what we already know. Kare- nin promises nothing, but will consider . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I told you I don't care about the divorce, so why hide the telegram? What else do you hide from me?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Why do you care about the divorce? What has it got to do with us loving each other?

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Until we're married, our daughter is legally Karenin's. I care about it because we need to be free to marry.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You're perfectly free to marry anyone your mother wants.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: But we aren't talking about--

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Yes, we are, and, by the way, compared to your mother I'm the Virgin Mary.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: Is there anything you wish to say to me?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: So it's the child.

Speaker: vronsky
Dialogue: She brought papers from Maman.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Unpack everything. We're not going.

Speaker: annushka
Dialogue: Anna Arkadyeva . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: When Count Vronsky comes back, tell him . . . I don't want to be disturbed.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Count Vronsky . . . ?

Speaker: annushka
Dialogue: He went out early, to the stables, he said.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Oh, Annushka . . . I should have died. Do you remember?

Speaker: annushka
Dialogue: Don't take it to heart, Anna Arkadyeva . . .

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I've made him hate me.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Count Vronsky had already left, Your Excel- lency. He took a cab to the station . . . to the Countess.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Are you waiting for the Princess Sorokina?

Speaker: maidservant
Dialogue: Look at that lace on her . . .

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: I'll be buying in feed before winter's over.

Speaker: theodore
Dialogue: Well, you don't press people hard, but you live rightly, for your soul, not your belly.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: My soul! What's that? I know what my belly is. How do we know what's rightly? I believe in reason.

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: theodore
Dialogue: You're a great one for reasoning, Konstantin Dmitrich, but what's rightly is outside your mathematic--that's what's rightly about it!

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: Where's Ekaterina Alexandrovna?

Speaker: agafia
Dialogue: It's all right, the mistress is giving Mitya his bath.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: And what was that?

Speaker: levin
Dialogue: He smiled at me.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: He's very advanced for his age.
